headline.main: Study Says Light Drinking Is Best for Women

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study on alcohol use and heart disease concludes that the ideal amount of alcohol for a woman appears to be no more than one to three drinks a week. Anything over that, and the benefits to longevity begin to disappear. Those who have more than two drinks a day actually increase their risk of death. The only women who benefited from drinking, however, were those over 50 who had at least one risk factor for heart trouble, like smoking, obesity, high blood pressure, diabetes, high cholesterol or a family history of heart disease.

headline.main: Personal Health; Common sense and conflicting health studies.

docs.lead_paragraph: MANY health-conscious Americans are understandably confused. Medical researchers cannot seem to make up their minds about what people should do to preserve their health for as long as possible. After years of advice to reduce fat intake to 30 percent of daily calories and to limit cholesterol consumption to less than 300 milligrams a day, the public learns that a British scientist has concluded after reviewing the best available studies that such a diet has a minimal -- if any -- effect on the incidence of heart disease and coronary death rates.

headline.main: Amid Inconclusive Health Studies, Some Experts Advise Less Advice

docs.lead_paragraph: AMID the deluge of health advice, health news, health tips and health warnings that swells ever larger each year, a number of public health experts and medical researchers are calling for a timeout. The public, they contend, should be told not just what the latest study says but also what it does not say, and how certain it is that the conclusion is correct. The most recent debates illustrate the problem, these experts say. In February, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued a statement saying any exercise was good, even the most modest activity. Then, last month, a study by Harvard University researchers concluded that only people who exercised regularly and strenuously would live longer.
